fractalnetworks package¶

Submodules¶

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality module¶

This module contains functions to analyse the betweenness centralities of nodes and edges in fractal and non-fractal networks.

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.analyse_betweenness_centrality(G, bcs=None)[source]¶

Returns key attributes of the betweenness centrality distribution of a network. Namely, finds the maximum, minimum and mean betweenness centrality, as well as the standard deviation and number of outliers with greater than expected betweenness.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – Network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

The maximum betweenness centrality in the network. min_bc (float): The minimum betweenness centrality in the network. mean_bc (float): The mean betweenness centrality in the network. stdv_bc (float): The standard deviation of the betweenness centrality distribution in the network. no_of_high_bc_nodes (int): Number of nodes with significantly higher betweenness centrality than expected. mean_max_bc (float): The mean betweenness centrality of the top 10% of nodes in the network.

Return type:

max_bc (float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation(G, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of the nodes in a network. Fractal networks are hypothesised to be less correlated in this regard than non-fractal networks.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation_hubs(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of the hub nodes in a network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of nodes indexes for hubs in the network. If no list is passed, the function with find the hubs with hub_method.

  • hub_method (func) – The method by which to calculate hubs, if not give. Default is identify_hubs.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calc_betweenness_degree_correlation_non_hubs(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculates the Pearson correlation coefficient for the degree and betweenness centrality of the non-hub nodes in a network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of nodes indexes for hubs in the network. If no list is passed, the function with find the hubs with hub_method.

  • hub_method (func) – The method by which to calculate hubs, if not give. Default is identify_hubs.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

Pearson’s correlation coefficient.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.calculate_r1(G, degrees=None)[source]¶
fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.edge_betweenness_degree_correlation(G, degrees=None, ebcs=None)[source]¶

Calculates the correlation between the betweenness centrality of edges and the degree of its endpoints.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • ebcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Calculates the correlation between the betweenness centrality of edges and the betweenness centrality of its endpoints.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • ebcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.find_betweenness_centralities(G)[source]¶

Calculates the normalised betweenness centrality distribution of the network.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities in the network. The i-th value is the betweenness centrality of the i-th node.

Return type:

(list)

Calculates the normalised betweenness centrality distribution of the network.

Returns:

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.find_hub_betweenness(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, bcs=None)[source]¶

Finds lists of betweenness centrality for the hubs and non-hubs in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities of hubs. non_hub_bcs (list): A list of betweenness centralities of non-hubs.

Return type:

hub_bcs (list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.hub_hub_path_betweenness(G, bcs=None, degrees=None, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, hub_hub_path_nodes=None)[source]¶

Analyses the betweenness of nodes on the paths between hubs with the number of their occurrences. Returns a list of the betweenness centralities of these nodes, and the Pearson correlation coefficient between the number of occurrences on such a path and their centrality.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • hub_hub_path_nodes (list) (opt) – A list of nodes on the paths between hubs. If None, this is calculated internally.

  • occurrences (dict) (opt) – A dictionary of hub path nodes and their number of occurrences. If None, this is calculated internally.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities belonging to nodes found on the paths between hubs.

Return type:

bcs_list (list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.hub_hub_path_betweenness_by_occurrence(G, bcs=None, degrees=None, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, hub_hub_path_nodes=None, occurrences=None)[source]¶

Analyses the betweenness of nodes on the paths between hubs with the number of their occurrences. Returns a list of the betweenness centralities of these nodes, and the Pearson correlation coefficient between the number of occurrences on such a path and their centrality.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • hub_hub_path_nodes (list) (opt) – A list of nodes on the paths between hubs. If None, this is calculated internally.

  • occurrences (dict) (opt) – A dictionary of hub path nodes and their number of occurrences. If None, this is calculated internally.

Returns:

A list of betweenness centralities belonging to nodes found on the paths between hubs.

Return type:

bcs_list (list)

fractalnetworks.betweennesscentrality.plot_betweenness_centralities(G, bcs=None, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots the betweenness centrality distribution of a given network on a histogram.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • bcs (list) (opt) – A list of betweenness centralities in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • save_path (str) (opt) – If a save path is given then the histogram is saved as a .png file. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) (opt) – If True, the histogram is displayed. Default is True.

Returns:

None

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation module¶

This module contains the code to renormalise a network using a box covering

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.assign_nodes_to_boxes(G, centres, central_distance)[source]¶

Generates a dictionary assigning each node to a box under the MEMB algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • centres (list) – A list of centre nodes according to the MEMB algorithm.

  • central_distance (dict) – A dictionary containing nodes as keys and their central distance as values.

Returns:

A dictionary containing nodes as keys and the box they are assigned to as the value.

Return type:

nodes_to_boxes (dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_boxes(nodes_to_boxes, centres)[source]¶

Finds a list of nodes assigned to each box in a network.

Parameters:

  • nodes_to_boxes (dict) – A dictionary with nodes as keys and their corresponding boxes as values.

  • centres (list) – A list of the nodes found as centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Returns:

A dictionary with boxes as keys and a list of nodes in that box as the value.

Return type:

boxes (dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_boxes_and_renormalise_iteration(G, lB, iter_count=1, filepath='graph', method=<function accelerated_MEMB>, draw=False)[source]¶

Performs one iteration of box covering and renormalisation. Stores all results in new files.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

  • iter_count (int) (opt) – The current iteration number. Default is 1 if no value is given.

  • filepath (str) (opt) – The path to which the resulting box covered and renormalised graphs will be saved. Default is “graph”.

  • method (func) (opt) – The MEMB method used to find the box covering. Default is degree_based_MEMB.

  • draw (Bool) (opt) – If True then display the networks. Default is False.

Returns:

The network after box renormalisation.

Return type:

renormalisedG (igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.find_central_distance(G, centres)[source]¶

Finds the central distance for each node in a network given a list of centres.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • centres (list) – A list of centre nodes from the MEMB algorithm.

Returns:

A dictionary containing nodes as keys and their central distance as values.

Return type:

central_distance (dict)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.renormalise_graph(G, boxes, nodes_to_boxes, draw=False)[source]¶

Renormalise a graph under a given box-covering.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • boxes (dict) – A dictionary with boxes as keys and a list of nodes in that box as the value.

  • nodes_to_boxes (dict) – A dictionary with nodes as keys and their corresponding boxes as values.

  • draw (Bool) (opt) – If True then displays the renormalised graph. Default is False.

Returns:

The network under renormalisation.

Return type:

renormalisedG (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.boxrenormalisation.renormalise_iteratively(filepath, lB, method=<function accelerated_MEMB>, draw=False)[source]¶

Iteratively finds the box covering and then renormalises the network until only one node is left.

Parameters:

  • filepath (str) – The filepath to the network file.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

  • method (func) (opt) – The MEMB method used to find the box covering. Default is degree_based_MEMB.

  • draw (Bool) (opt) – If True then display the networks. Default is False.

Returns:

None

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality module¶

This module contians the functions needed to determine if a given network is fractal or non-fractal

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.calculate_lB_NB_dist(G, diam=None, method=<function degree_based_MEMB>, min_lB=3)[source]¶

Finds the distribution of the optimal number of boxes NB against the diameter of these boxes lB.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • diam (int) (opt) – The diameter of the network G. The default is None, and note that if no diameter is given the algorithm will calculate it which is expensive for large networks.

  • method (func) – The method used to calculate the box covering. Default is the degree based amended MEMB algorithm (see [2]).

  • min_lB (int) – The first value of lB to calculate NB from. Default is 3.

Returns:

List of values for the box diameters lB. NB (list): List of the corresponding optimal number of boxes.

Return type:

lB (list)

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.is_fractal(G, diam=None, plot=False, verbose=False, normalise=False, lB_min=2, save_path=None, colouring_ordering_method=None, step=1)[source]¶

Determines whether a network is fractal or not depending on the sum of squares regression score for the fractal and exponential fits.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • diam (int) – The diameter of the graph. If None, calculates the diameter. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) – If True, plot a comparison of the best fits. Default is False.

  • verbose (Bool) – If True, print statements with the fractal and non fractal values. Default is False.

Returns:

A list of box diameters for the covering. NB (list): A list of the number of boxes needed to cover the network. (Bool): True if the network is determined to be fractal, False otherwise.

Return type:

lB (list)

fractalnetworks.determiningfractality.is_fractal_by_logarithm(G, diam=None, plot=False, verbose=False, normalise=False, lB_min=2, save_path=None, colouring_ordering_method=None)[source]¶

Determines whether a network is fractal or not depending on the sum of squares regression score for the fractal and exponential fits.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • diam (int) – The diameter of the graph. If None, calculates the diameter. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) – If True, plot a comparison of the best fits. Default is False.

  • verbose (Bool) – If True, print statements with the fractal and non fractal values. Default is False.

Returns:

A list of box diameters for the covering. NB (list): A list of the number of boxes needed to cover the network. (Bool): True if the network is determined to be fractal, False otherwise.

Return type:

lB (list)

fractalnetworks.greedyalgorithm.make_dual_graph(graph, lB)[source]¶

Finds the dual graph as defined under the greedy colouring algorithm. In the dual graph, two nodes are connected if the distance between them is at least lB.

Parameters:

  • graph (igraph.Graph) – The graph to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

Returns:

The dual graph.

Return type:

dual_graph (igraph.Graph)

Orders nodes using the smallest last [3] method.

G (igraph.Graph) – The network being ordered.

Returns:

A list of the nodes in order.

Return type:

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion module¶

This file contains function to analyse the effect of hub-hub repulsion in fractal networks.

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.calculate_HCS(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Calculate the Hub Connectivity Score (HCS) of the network. This is the average number of hubs each hub is adjacent to.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

The Hub Connectivity Score of the network.

Return type:

(float)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.find_degree_distribution(G)[source]¶

Calculates the degree distribution of the network.

Returns:

A list of degrees in the network. The i-th value is the degree of the i-th node.

Return type:

(list)

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Identify the hubs of the network using the Z-score, where hubs are those nodes with Z > 3.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

A list of nodes with Z > 3.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.identify_hubs_by_mean(G, degrees=None, factor=2)[source]¶

Identify the hubs of the network using the mean, where hubs are those nodes with degree greater than some factor (usually 2) times the mean.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • factor (int) (opt) – The factor by which the mean is multiplied to identify hubs. Default is 2.

Returns:

A list of hubs.

Return type:

(list)

fractalnetworks.hubrepulsion.identify_hubs_by_percentile(G, degrees=None, percentile=90)[source]¶

Identify the hubs of the network by percentile, where hubs are those in some percentile of the degree distribution (normally 90%)

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

  • percentile (int) (opt) – The percentile hubs belong to. Default is 90.

Returns:

A list of hubs.

Return type:

(list)

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning module¶

This module contains MEMB algorithms

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.MEMB(G, lB, deterministic=True)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning algorithm as according to [1], with some time improvements. In this version, the nodes within a radius r_B of a node are only found once, and then updated using the list of covered nodes. Note: Only works for odd numbers of lB, otherwise it takes rB to be the floor of (lB-1)/2 which is the same as for the odd lB-1.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

  • deterministic (Bool) (opt) – If False, choose fom nodes with equal excluded mass randomly. If True, choose the first lexicographically.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

centres (list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.accelerated_MEMB(G, lB)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning algorithm as according to [1], with accelerated performance. Rather than calculating the excluded mass for all nodes at each stage, calculate the excluded mass of the node with the next highest excluded mass in the previous stage. Then reject all nodes with excluded mass in the previous stage less than this value (excluded mass can only decrease between stages) Repeat until only one node is left, and this becomes the next p. Note: Only works for odd numbers of lB, otherwise it takes rB to be the floor of (lB-1)/2 which is the same as for the odd lB-1.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

centres (list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.calc_next_iter(G, uncovered, N, dc, eg_dict, rB, centres, p, failed)[source]¶

Finds the top N nodes to check in the next iteration of the algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network being analysed.

  • uncovered (list) – A list of nodes in the network which are uncovered at this stage.

  • N (int) – The number of nodes to check in the next iteration of the algorithm.

  • dc (dict) – Dictionary containing the degree centrality of each node which is yet to be checked as a centre.

  • eg_dict (dict) – Dictionary with keys as nodes and values as the list of nodes within a distance of rB from that node.

  • rB (int) – The radius rB to be checked.

  • centres (list) – List of nodes identified as centres.

  • p (str) – Name of the node chosen as the most recent p [1].

  • failed (Bool) – True if the previous iteration of the algorithm failed, and False otherwise.

Returns:

Returns an updated version of eg_dict with the nodes to be checked for the next iteration.

Return type:

eg_dict (dict)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.degree_based_MEMB(G, lB, deterministic=True, N=10, verbose=False)[source]¶

Implements the Maximal Excluded Mass Burning algorithm as according to [1], adjusted to prioritise nodes with high degree. This reduces the running time of the traditional MEMB without losing accuracy. Note: Only works for odd numbers of lB, otherwise it takes rB to be the floor of (lB-1)/2 which is the same as for the odd lB-1.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

  • deterministic (Bool) (opt) – If False, choose fom nodes with equal excluded mass randomly. If True, choose the first lexicographically.

  • N (int) – Takes the top N-th nodes by degree to find the centred subgraph of.

Returns:

A list of nodes assigned to be centres under the MEMB algorithm.

Return type:

centres (list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.degree_centrality(G)[source]¶

Calculates a dictionary of the degree centralities for all nodes in a graph. Analagous to the NetworkX degree_centrality method.

Parameters:

G (igraph.Graph) – The network the algorithm is to be applied to.

Returns:

A dictionary with node labels as keys and their degree centralities as the values.

Return type:

dc (dict)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.distance_based_MEMB(G, lB)[source]¶

Calculates the centres for each lB from lB_min to the diameter of the network by first calculating the shortest path distance between every pair of nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB_min (int) (opt) – The minimum diameter of the boxes for the box covering.

Returns:

A list of centres found by the algorithm.

Return type:

centres (list)

lB (list)

fractalnetworks.maximumexcludedmassburning.find_next_centre(G, covered, rB, ordered_list, number_EM_calcs)[source]¶

Find the node with the next highest excluded mass to be the next centre.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • covered (list) – A list of indices for the covered nodes in the network at the current stage.

  • rB (int) – The radius of boxes to be found.

  • ordered_list (list) – A list of tuples containing the nodes of the network and their most recently updated excluded mass, in decreasing order of excluded mass.

Returns:

An updated version of the ordered list. p (tuple): The new centre value and its excluded mass.

Return type:

ordered_list (list)

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes used to cover the network.

  • deterministic (Bool) (opt) – If False, choose fom nodes with equal excluded mass randomly. If True, choose the first lexicographically.

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator module¶

This module contains functions to generate instances of known fractal network models

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.HADG_iteration(G, m, a, b, T)[source]¶

Performs one iteration of the HADG generative process [4][5].

Parameters:

  • G (networkx.Graph) – The network in its current state.

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as according to [5].

  • a (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge if node degree is over the threshold [5].

  • b (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge otherwise [5].

  • T (float) – The threshold as according to [5].

Returns:

The updated network.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.SHM_iteration(G, m, p)[source]¶

Performs one iteration of the generative process for the SHM model.

Parameters:

  • G (networkx.Graph) – The network from the previous generation.

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as defined by the SHM model [3].

  • p (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge, as defined by the SHM model [3]. The value of p should be between 0 and 1.

Returns:

The network in the new generation.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.add_m_offspring(G, node, m)[source]¶

Adds m offspring to a given node, connected by a single edge.

Parameters:

  • G (networkx.Graph) – The network in its current state.

  • node (int) – The node to which the offspring are to be added.

  • m (int) – The number of offspring.

Returns:

The updated network. new_nodes (list): A list of the names of all the new nodes added at the previous stage.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.add_new_path(l, N, edge)[source]¶

Adds a new parallel path to the network, a step in the (u, v)-flower generation process.

Parameters:

  • l (int) – The length of the path to be added to the network.

  • N (int) – A counter which stores the next unused integer to label nodes.

  • edge (tuple) – The edge from the network being replaced with parallel paths.

Returns:

A path graph of length l with vertices labelled correctly. N (int): A counter which stores the next unused integer to label nodes.

Return type:

Hl (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.generate_HADG_model(m, a, b, T, n, save=False)[source]¶

Generates an nth generation HADG network with parameters m, a, b and T [4][5].

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as according to [5].

  • a (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge if node degree is over the threshold [5].

  • b (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge otherwise [5].

  • T (float) – The threshold as according to [5].

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the HADG generative process.

  • save (Bool) (opt) – If True, saved the resulting network to a gml file. Default is False.

Returns:

The resulting HADG network.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.generate_SHM_model(m, p, n, save=False)[source]¶

Generates an n-th generation SHM network with parameters m and p.

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as defined by the SHM model [3].

  • p (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge, as defined by the SHM model [3]. The value of p should be between 0 and 1.

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the SHM generative process [3].

  • save (bool) (opt) – If True, the file is saved to the network-files folder. Default is False.

Returns:

The generated SHM network.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.modelgenerator.generate_SHM_model_for_all_p(m, n, prob_N=11, example_N=1, save=False)[source]¶

Generate SHM networks for a fixed m and n, for multiple values of p.

Parameters:

  • m (int) – The number of offspring added at each stage, as defined by the SHM model [3].

  • n (int) – The number of iterations to perform of the SHM generative process [3].

  • prob_N (int) – The number of probabilities to generate the graph for. Default is 11, so will generate networks with p in [0.0, 0.1, 0.2, …, 0.9, 1.0]

  • example_N (int) (opt) – The number of networks of each probability to generate. Default is 1.

  • save (Bool) (opt) – If True, save each of the networks to a .gml file. Default is False.

Returns:

A list of the probabilities which are used. graphs (list): A list of lists of generated networks. The sublist graphs[i] contains graphs with p=probabilities[i].

Return type:

probabilities (numpy.ndarray)

  • p (float) – The probability of rewiring an edge, as defined by the SHM model [3].

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.hub_distance_distribution(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, degrees=None)[source]¶

Find the distribution of distances between hubs.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

A dictionary with distances as keys, the probability of two hubs being separated by that distance as the values.

Return type:

distance_distributions (dict)

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.mean_hub_distance(G, hubs=None, hub_method=<function identify_hubs>, normalised=False, degrees=None)[source]¶

Finds the mean distance between hubs. The normalised mean distance is the mean distance between hubs over the mean distance between any pair of nodes in the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • hubs (list) (opt) – A list of hubs in the network, If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function finds the hubs.

  • hub_method (func) (opt) – If the hubs are to be calculated, then this parameter specifies the method used to find hubs. Default is identify_hubs, which uses the Z score.

  • normalised (Bool) (opt) – If true, the distances are normalised over the average distance in the network. Default is False.

  • degrees (list) (opt) – A list of degrees in the network. If already calculated, this parameter can be passed to prevent duplication. Default is None, in which case the function calculates the distribution internally.

Returns:

The mean distance between pairs of hubs in the network. hub_distances (list): A list of distances between pairs of hubs.

Return type:

mean_distance (float)

fractalnetworks.networkproperties.summarise_graph(G, skip_diam=False, skip_aspl=False)[source]¶

Summarises the key attributes of a given network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • skip_diam (Bool) (opt) – If True, then do not calculate the diameter of the graph. This is recommended for large graphs. The default is False.

  • skip_aspl (Bool) (opt) – If True, then do not calculate the average shortest path length of the graph. This is recommended for large graphs. The default is False.

Returns:

None

  • ebcs (list) (opt) – A list of edge betweenness centralities. If already calculated, it can be passed as an argument to prevent duplication. Default is None, meaning it will be calculated internally.

H (igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.networkskeleton.find_skeleton_edge_betweenness(G, H=None, ebcs=None)[source]¶

Finds the edge betweenness centralities of edges in the skeleton of the network.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • H (igraph.Graph) (opt) – The skeleton of the network, if known. Default is None.

  • ebcs (list) (opt) – The edge betweenness centralities of the network, if known. Default is None.

Returns:

A list of edge betweenness centralities of edges in the skeleton. non_skeleton_ebcs (list): A list of edge betweenness centralities of edges not in the skeleton.

Return type:

skeleton_ebcs (list)

fractalnetworks.networkskeleton.find_skeleton_eids(G, H=None, ebcs=None)[source]¶

Finds a list of edge IDs for edges in the skeleton of G.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • H (igraph.Graph) (opt) – The skeleton of the network, if known. Default is None.

  • ebcs (list) (opt) – The edge betweenness centralities of the network, if known. Default is None.

Returns:

List of IDs of edges in G which are in the skeleton of G.

skeleton_edges (list)

fractalnetworks.randomsequential module¶

Implements the Random Sequential box covering algorithm

fractalnetworks.randomsequential.random_sequential(G, lB)[source]¶

Implements the random sequential box covering algorithm.

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • lB (int) – The diameter of the boxes.

Returns:

A list of centre nodes found by the algorithm. boxes (list): A list of lists, where each sublist is a box under the box-covering algorithm.

Return type:

centres (list)

fractalnetworks.utilities module¶

This module contains utility functions used throughout the fractal network toolkit.

  • list2 (list) – The list to be plotted on the y-axis, to be checked for NaN values.

  • save_path (str) (opt) – The filepath to save the figure to, if given. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) (opt) – If True, the network is displayed inline. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.utilities.exact_log(x, y)[source]¶

Finds the exact logarithm of x base y.

Parameters:

  • x (int) – The value of x.

  • y (int) – The logarithm base.

Returns:

The floor of the power, where y^power = x. x==1 (Bool): True if x is an exact power of y, False otherwise.

Return type:

power (int)

fractalnetworks.utilities.export_to_gephi(G, nodes_to_boxes, file_path)[source]¶

Puts graphs in a format readable to Gephi including attributes for the boxes found under box coverings.

Parameters:

  • G (networkx.Graph) – The network to be analysed.

  • nodes_to_boxes (dict) – A dictionary with nodes as keys and their corresponding boxes as values.

  • file_path (str) – The path for the gml file to be saved to.

Returns:

None

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_exp_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, linspace_N=100)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit of the form y = Ae^{-cx} according to the sum of squares deviation.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 100.

  • c_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 2.

  • linspace_N (int) (opt) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

The coefficients A and c from the best exponential approximation. best_score (float): The sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

best_fit (tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_fit_iteratively(x, y, method, linspace_N=100, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, iter_num=4)[source]¶

Finds the best fit according to a given model by iteratively reducing the range of values checked for A and c.

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • method (func) – A function which finds the best fit to the given distribution according to a given model.

  • linspace_N (int) (opt) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

  • A_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • iter_num (int) (opt) – The number of iterations to complete.

Returns:

The coefficients A and c from the best approximation. best_score (float): The sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

best_fit (tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.find_best_fractal_fit(x, y, A_min=0, A_max=10000, c_min=0, c_max=12.5, linspace_N=100)[source]¶

Finds the best exponential fit according to the sum of squares deviation of the form y = Ax^{-c}

Parameters:

  • x (list) – The values of x in the distribution.

  • y (list) – The values of y in the distribution.

  • A_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • A_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of A to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 10000.

  • c_min (int) (opt) – The minimum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 0.

  • c_max (int) (opt) – The maximum value of c to be tested. Can be adjusted to find more accurate results. Default is 12.5.

  • linspace_N (int) (opt) – The number of values of A and c to be checked in the respective ranges. Default is 100.

Returns:

The coefficients A and c from the best power law approximation. best_score (float): The sum of squares regression of this approximation.

Return type:

best_fit (tuple)

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_best_fit_comparison(lB, NB, exp_A, exp_c, exp_score, frac_A, frac_c, frac_score)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the best power law (fractal) and exponential (non-fractal) fit for a given distribution.

Parameters:

  • lB (list) – List of the values of lB.

  • NB (list) – List of the corresponding values of NB.

  • exp_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the exponential fit.

  • exp_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the exponential best fit.

  • frac_A (float) – The optimal value of A according to the power law fit.

  • frac_c (float) – The optimal value of c according to the power law fit.

  • frac_score (float) – The sum of squares regression for the power law best fit.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_scatter_graph(fractal_attribute, non_fractal_attribute, fractal_Ns, non_fractal_Ns, y_label, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the properties of fractal and non-fractal networks on a scatter graph.

Parameters:

  • fractal_attributes (list) – A list of an attribute of fractal networks.

  • non_fractal_attributes (list) – A list of an attribute of non-fractal networks.

  • fractal_Ns (list) – A list of fractal network orders.

  • non_fractal_Ns (list) – A list of non-fractal network orders.

  • y_label (str) – Label for the y-axis, i.e. the attribute being plotted.

  • save_path (str) (opt) – The file path to save the figure to, if given. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) (opt) – If True, display the network. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.utilities.plot_scatter_graph_random_networks(fractal_attribute, random_attribute, fractal_Ns, random_Ns, y_label, save_path=None, plot=True)[source]¶

Plots a comparison of the properties of fractal networks and their random counterparts on a scatter graph.

Parameters:

  • fractal_attributes (list) – A list of an attribute of fractal networks.

  • random_attributes (list) – A list of an attribute of the random networks.

  • fractal_Ns (list) – A list of fractal network orders.

  • random_Ns (list) – A list of random network orders.

  • y_label (str) – Label for the y-axis, i.e. the attribute being plotted.

  • save_path (str) (opt) – The file path to save the figure to, if given. Default is None.

  • plot (Bool) (opt) – If True, display the network. Default is True.

fractalnetworks.utilities.read_graph(filepath)[source]¶

Checks the filetype and calls the correct function to read the graph. For any file not in .gml format, an additional .gml file is created. Currently supports .mtx, .txt, .edge (.EDGE) and .gml filetypes.

Parameters:

filepath (str) – Path for the network file.

Returns:

The network from the file stored as a graph.

Return type:

G (igraph.Graph)

fractalnetworks.utilities.read_mtx_graph_format(filepath)[source]¶

Reads graphs stored in the .mtx file format. Use with, for example, graphs from www.networkrepository.com. Note: Some files may need to be edited to make sure that scipy.io can read them. Files should have a header starting with %%MatrixMarket and a single line denoted the number of values in each column.

Parameters:

filepath (str) – Filepath to .mtx file

Returns:

Network read from file.

Return type:

G (networkx.Graph)

fractalnetworks.utilities.sum_of_squares_error(y, est_y)[source]¶

Finds the value SSR for the sum of squares regression method using a true and model distribution.

Parameters:

  • y (list) – The true or measured distribution.

  • est_y (list) – The model distribution to be compared.

Returns:

The sum of squares regression

Return type:

sum_of_squares (float)

fractalnetworks.utilities.swap_edges_at_random(G, number_edges_to_swap)[source]¶

Swaps edge of a given network at random, to find an uncorrelated network with the same degree distribution. Removes two randomly chosen edges (a,b) and (c,d) and replaces them with edges (a,d) and (c,b).

Parameters:

  • G (igraph.Graph) – The original network.

  • number_edges_to_swap (int) – The number of edges to swap.

Returns:

The new, uncorrelated network with the same degree distribution as G.

Return type:

H (igraph.Graph)

Module contents¶

Import fractalnetworks to use the fractal network toolkit. This module contains functions for the analysis of fractal networks.

Fractal Networks
